channel.title: Help
channel.description:
I need a method which will return an array of URL's host name in a file.
if the URL is http://example.com or www.example.com or example.com or any of the before with a file (example.com/something.php)
it would return example.com
the file is an html file, like from a web site. so it will vary on the extension, .net, .org, .anything :/
greatly appreciated
in another note :
i am attempting to make a sort of proxy web browser, you see my school blocks websites through their proxy which is the only connection to Internet. but it blocks the websites by the name of the websites, not by the IP and since URLs can also have the IP like : http://127.0.0.1/index.php, it would basically unblock a URL :\ ;)

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

o yeh, the asterisk isnt meant to be there

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

yea, i made a simple pattern because the 1 u gave me had an error on the asterisk, this seems to work : “(http://|www[.]).+[.][a-zA-Z]/” the parts in parenthesis being the start, the a-zA-Z being the .com and such :\ is there a way to make the chars have a length? like the extension i belive th max is for with .info being the largest right?

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

[quote=“nueb35, post:4, topic:177148”][quote author=k00dr link=topic=237996.msg2022814#msg2022814 date=1201723114]
http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/overview-summary.html

URL url = new URL("http://www.example.com/file.txt");
String host = url.getHost();

[/quote]

maby i didnt explain well, i need it to get the url from a .html file, and find the urls in it, not how to get the host name… that i can do my self after i got the url, and i put it into a new url object >.>[/quote]

Ohh, alright

I believe you can find a valid regex pattern here and here’s a Sun’s tutorial if you want to do it yourself.

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

that pattern should be correct

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:5, topic:177148”]Pattern pattern = Pattern.compile("(?:http://)?(?:www\\.)?(*.+?)/"); Matcher matcher = pattern.matcher(thecontentsofthefilethatyoureadtheurlsfrom); List<String> urls = new ArrayList<String>(); while (matcher.find()) { urls.add(matcher.group(1); }
or similar[/quote]

oo never thought of paters :0 ill look into that when i get home thanks

sadly i never used patterns, and i duno how to use em. google isnt helping much, care 2 find me a good tut, or do the pattern for me

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

Pattern pattern = Pattern.compile("(?:http://)?(?:www\\.)?(*.+?)/"); Matcher matcher = pattern.matcher(thecontentsofthefilethatyoureadtheurlsfrom); List<String> urls = new ArrayList<String>(); while (matcher.find()) { urls.add(matcher.group(1); }
or similar

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“k00dr, post:2, topic:177148”]http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/overview-summary.html

URL url = new URL("http://www.example.com/file.txt");
String host = url.getHost();
[/code][/quote]

maby i didnt explain well, i need it to get the url from a .html file, and find the urls in it, not how to get the host name... that i can do my self after i got the url, and i put it into a new url object >.>[br][br][size=1]Posted on: January 30, 2008, 10:55:51 AM[/size][hr][quote="Taharok, post:3, topic:177148"][code]
String s = "http://example.com/file.txt";
s = s.substring(s.indexOf("//"));
s = s.substring(0, s.indexOf("/"));

That should work. It cuts off the “http://” part and then cuts off the rest of the address after the first “/”.[/quote]

yes but as i sayd in the post, it wont always have http:// it might have www. or not even have www or http://

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

String s = "http://example.com/file.txt";
s = s.substring(s.indexOf("//"));
s = s.substring(0, s.indexOf("/"));

That should work. It cuts off the “http://” part and then cuts off the rest of the address after the first “/”.

Read full topic
